Source: PubMed 

Topic: Statin use associated with reduced risk of subarachnoid hemorrhage

Study details:
This large case-control study used Japan’s Health Insurance Claims Database (2005–2021) to assess the link between statin use and first-ever subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). A total of 3,498 SAH cases were matched with 13,992 controls by age, sex, and follow-up. Statin exposure was assessed prior to SAH, and models adjusted for comorbidities.

Results:
▪️Statin use was reported in 12.2% of cases vs. 12.7% of controls.
▪️Statin use was associated with a 19% lower risk of SAH (adjusted odds ratio: 0.81, 95% CI: 0.69–0.95).
▪️The protective effect was stronger in those with hypertension or cerebrovascular disease.

Clinical impact:
Statins may reduce SAH risk, especially in high-risk patients. While promising, causal conclusions require further study.

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/40625226/

Source: PubMed 

Topic: Risk of Intracranial Hemorrhage With Apixaban Versus Aspirin Therapy: A Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials

Study details: This meta-analysis evaluated the relative risk of intracranial hemorrhage (ICH) with apixaban vs. aspirin in ischemic stroke prevention. Researchers reviewed randomized controlled trials from major databases, including only those reporting ICH events. Three trials met inclusion criteria, encompassing 10,626 patients and 74 ICH events. 

Results:
▪️ICH risk: Apixaban showed a non-significant but lower relative risk of ICH vs. aspirin (RR: 0.67; 95% CI: 0.43–1.08; P=0.10)
▪️Hemorrhagic stroke: Similar trend (RR: 0.72; 95% CI: 0.39–1.31)
Findings were consistent in sensitivity analyses.

Link: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/40464082/

Topic: Change to Step 2 CK Passing Standard Begins July 1, 2025 | USMLE

At its June 2025 meeting, the USMLE Management Committee conducted a review of the USMLE Step 2 Clinical Knowledge (CK) passing standard. Management Committee members include individuals with experience on state medical boards, medical school and residency program faculty from across the United States, practicing physicians, residents, and public members. The Committee decided that a four-point increase in the passing standard – used to determine a Pass or Fail outcome – will apply to Step 2 CK examinees testing on or after July 1, 2025.  On the three-digit score scale, the passing standard will change from 214 to 218.

Source: FDA

Topic: Mavyret now approved for the treatment of acute hepatitis C infection 

FDA approved Mavyret (glecaprevir/pibrentasvir) for the treatment of adults and pediatric patients ≥3 years of age with acute or chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) genotype 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 or 6 infection without cirrhosis or with compensated cirrhosis (Child-Pugh A).

The efficacy of Mavyret in subjects with documented acute HCV infection was evaluated in M20-350 (NCT04903626), a single-arm, open-label study of 286 adults who were treatment-naïve for the current infection and received Mavyret for 8 weeks. The overall rate of sustained virological response 12 weeks post treatment (SVR12) was 96%, with no patients experiencing virologic failure. Two patients who didn’t achieve SVR12 were likely reinfected with HCV based on having different HCV genotypes or subtype clades between baseline and follow-up periods.

Link: https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2025/209394s019,215110s005lbl.pdf

Topic: FDA greenlights first twice-yearly injection for HIV prevention 

Brand name: Yeztugo
Generic name: lenacapavir
Approval date: June 18, 2025

FDA approved Yeztugo (lenacapavir), an injectable HIV-1 capsid inhibitor, as pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) to reduce the risk of sexually acquired HIV-1 in adults and adolescents weighing ≥35kg who are at increased risk for disease. Individuals must have a negative HIV-1 test prior to initiating Yeztugo.
Lenacapravir is also approved for HIV treatment under the brand name Sunlenca.

Efficacy 
In phase 3 trials (PURPOSE 1 & 2), twice-yearly subcutaneous Yeztugo showed near-complete protection against HIV:
▪️0 infections in 2,134 women (PURPOSE 1)
▪️99.9% remained uninfected in 2,179 men and gender-diverse participants (PURPOSE 2)

Common side effects (≥5%): injection site reactions, headache, nausea

Link: https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2025/220020s000lbl.pdf

Red Blood Cell Transfusion 2023 AABB International Guidelines summary of the recommendations:

Source: https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/article-abstract/2810754

1. Hospitalized adults (hemodynamically stable): A restrictive transfusion strategy is recommended, with transfusions considered when hemoglobin falls below 7 g/dL (strong recommendation, moderate certainty evidence). For patients undergoing cardiac surgery, a threshold of 7.5 g/dL may be used, and for orthopedic surgery or those with preexisting cardiovascular disease, 8 g/dL may be considered.

2. Adults with hematologic or oncologic disorders: A restrictive transfusion strategy is suggested, with transfusions considered when hemoglobin is less than 7 g/dL (conditional recommendation, low certainty evidence).

3. Critically ill children: For hemodynamically stable children without conditions such as hemoglobinopathy, cyanotic cardiac conditions, or severe hypoxemia, a restrictive transfusion strategy is recommended, considering transfusion when hemoglobin is less than 7 g/dL (strong recommendation, moderate certainty evidence).

4. Children with congenital heart disease: Transfusion thresholds vary based on the heart abnormality and the stage of surgical repair:
   - Biventricular repair: 7 g/dL
   - Single-ventricle palliation: 9 g/dL
   - Uncorrected congenital heart disease: 7 to 9 g/dL (conditional recommendation, low certainty evidence).

Source: PubMed 

Topic: Higher Rate of Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis Recurrence With Secondary Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis Prophylaxis Compared With No Prophylaxis in 2 National Cirrhosis Cohorts

Background:
With rising antibiotic resistance, the role of secondary spontaneous bacterial peritonitis prophylaxis (SecSBPPr) in cirrhosis is uncertain. This study assessed its real-world impact.

Methods:
Using VA and TriNetX databases (2009–2019), we identified >11,000 adults who survived a first SBP episode. Outcomes were compared between those who received SecSBPPr and those who did not.

Results:
SecSBPPr was prescribed in ~50% of cases. In both cohorts, it was linked to a significantly higher risk of SBP recurrence (HR 1.63–1.68; P<0.001) and, in the VA group, to increased fluoroquinolone resistance (OR 4.32; P=0.03). Recurrence risk worsened over time.

Conclusion:
SecSBPPr was associated with increased SBP recurrence and resistance, suggesting the need to reconsider its routine use in cirrhosis.

Link: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/39235290/

𝐁𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐌𝐲 𝐒𝐦𝐢𝐥𝐞 𝐁𝐚𝐜𝐤!!

Eleven years ago, I was a hopeful intern  smiling, energetic, and eager. But over time, those smiles faded, replaced by the daily heartbreak of watching patients suffer in a failing health system.

I’ll never forget the night a barefoot mother rushed in, clutching her feverish, gasping son. Severe pneumonia. He needed oxygen, antibiotics, tests but the hospital had none. No oxygen. No meds. No lab support. She had no money. I had no choice.

I ran through wards begging. Found one oxygen cylinder in surgery begged again. Dragged it down. Paid for his meds. Paid for his labs. Not because I can afford, but because I had no choice.

He lived. She wept. I cried not from exhaustion, but from despair. Because saving a child shouldn’t demand such desperation.

The next day, no one asked. No one cared. Just another shift. Just another life nearly lost.

And I still ask: Why must we beg to do our jobs?

We’re not asking for luxury. Just the basics:
⚕️ Medications.
💡 Supplies.
🧍‍♂️ Fair pay.
🫱🏽‍🫲🏾 Dignity.

To all who shape policies and budgets: don’t wait until the healers are broken. The strength of any healthcare system lies in its people. 

𝐒𝐮𝐩𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭 𝐮𝐬. 𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐩𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐮𝐬. 𝐄𝐪𝐮𝐢𝐩 𝐮𝐬. 𝐏𝐚𝐲 𝐮𝐬 𝐟𝐚𝐢𝐫. 
Somewhere out there, another intern is facing that same night. Let’s make sure they don’t have to do it alone.

✍🏽Dr. Segenet Bizuneh 
Associate Professor of Internal Medicine 
University of Gondar

Ethiopia Health Cluster reports rise in Cholera, Malaria, and Measles cases

Between January and April 2025, Ethiopia reported 4,056 cholera cases and 42 deaths, with active outbreaks in 32 districts and five refugee camps, primarily in the #Amhara and #Gambella regions. Notably, 89.9% of the cases in Amhara originated from just four woredas.

Malaria cases also surged, reaching 1.97 million with 77 deaths. In April alone, 1,147 woredas reported cases, with Gambella recording the highest incidence rate at 462 cases per 100,000 population.

Measles outbreaks remain ongoing, with 3,908 cases and 22 deaths reported. Eight regions, including Amhara, Oromia, and #Tigray, are currently affected. In late April, 96 new cases were recorded in Deder district, Oromia.

🗞 Medical Articles

Source: PubMed 

Topic: AI-assisted insulin titration improves glycemic control in type 2 diabetes

Study details:
A multicenter, single-blind RCT (N=149; NCT04642378) compared an AI-driven insulin clinical decision support system (iNCDSS) with senior endocrinologists for insulin titration in hospitalized adults with T2DM over five days.

Results:
Time in target glucose range (70–180 mg/dL) was 76.4% with iNCDSS vs. 73.6% with physicians, meeting the noninferiority margin (difference: 2.7%; 95% CI: -2.7% to 8.0%). Secondary outcomes and adverse events were similar. Physicians rated iNCDSS highly for clarity, efficiency, and safety.

Clinical impact:
iNCDSS may be a reliable tool for inpatient insulin management, potentially improving workflow and maintaining glycemic safety.

Link: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/40332936/

Senior Physicians: It’s Time to Step Forward
Dr Muluken A. (Assistant Professor Pediatric Cardiologist)

As a senior physician, I’ve seen how our healthcare system is under immense pressure. We are not exempt from the burden—many of us struggle with inadequate salaries, delayed duty payments, lack of health insurance, and the soaring cost of living that makes it difficult to cover even basic expenses like rent and food. On top of that, emotional fatigue and professional burnout are becoming more common among us.

Yet despite all this, most of us remain silent. Some are afraid of administrative repercussions; others are worn down by years of unmet demands. A few manage to cushion the impact through private work and choose to stay quiet. Many of us work in teaching hospitals where the hierarchy is so rigid that interns and residents hesitate to raise concerns openly with us. I’ve experienced this personally—when I tried to bring these issues up, I was met with avoidance, not engagement.

But silence will not protect us, nor will it fix the system. We, as senior physicians, must speak out—in staff meetings, academic circles, and professional associations. We should mentor through solidarity, encouraging younger colleagues to speak safely and openly. We must use our influence to push for real policy changes and show that leadership includes advocacy. If we don’t take the lead in defending the dignity of our profession, who will?

#SeniorDoctorsRise #ReclaimOurProfession #SpeakUpForHealthcare

We extend our deepest condolences to his family, friends, colleagues, and all those whose lives he touched. His legacy of kindness, dedication, and service will continue to inspire generations to come.  

May his soul rest in eternal peace.

Source: PubMed 

Topic: Macrolide therapy tied to reduced cardiovascular events in bronchiectasis

Study details:
This territory-wide cohort study analyzed 22,895 patients diagnosed with bronchiectasis classified as macrolide maintenance therapy (MMT) receivers or non-receivers in Hong Kong from 2001 to 2018. The primary outcome was major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE), including CV death, MI, and stroke. Safety outcomes included ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death.

Results:
MMT use was associated with a significantly lower rate of MACE (16.4 vs. 24.1 per 1,000 person-years; HR 0.68, 95% CI 0.52–0.90). There was no significant increase in the risk of ventricular arrhythmias or sudden cardiac death (HR 0.93; 95% CI 0.60–1.44)..

Clinical impact:
MMT may offer cardiovascular protection in bronchiectasis, beyond reducing exacerbations.

Link: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/39603670/

Source: PubMed

Topic: SGLT2 inhibitors may protect against hyperkalemia in patients on RAAS inhibitors

Study details:
A Canadian retrospective cohort study of adults ≥66 years with diabetes, heart failure, or CKD on RAAS inhibitors compared 20,063 SGLT2i users to 19,781 nonusers.

Results:
SGLT2i use was linked to reduced hyperkalemia risk (HR 0.89; 95% CI 0.82–0.96) and fewer hospitalizations. RAASi discontinuation was lower in SGLT2i users (36% vs. 45%; P<.001).

Clinical impact:
The findings suggest that SGLT2 inhibitors can mitigate the risk of hyperkalemia in patients receiving RAASi, potentially improving adherence to RAASi therapy and enhancing overall clinical outcomes for patients with diabetes, heart failure, or chronic kidney disease.

Link: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/40293730/
